## Univariate Analysis

```{r univariate}
library(ggplot2)
library(dplyr)

df <- read.csv("../../data/breast_cancer.csv", stringsAsFactors = FALSE)
numerical_cols <- setdiff(names(df), c("id", "diagnosis"))

key_features <- c("radius_mean", "texture_mean", "perimeter_mean", 
                 "area_mean", "smoothness_mean", "compactness_mean")

# Distribution plots
for (feature in key_features[1:3]) {
  hist(df[[feature]], main = paste("Distribution of", feature), 
      xlab = feature, col = "steelblue")
}
```

## Bivariate Analysis

```{r bivariate}
# Scatter plots
plot(df$radius_mean, df$perimeter_mean, 
    col = ifelse(df$diagnosis == "M", "red", "blue"),
    xlab = "radius_mean", ylab = "perimeter_mean",
    main = "Bivariate Analysis: Radius vs Perimeter")
legend("topright", legend = c("Malignant", "Benign"), 
      col = c("red", "blue"), pch = 1)
```

## Multivariate Analysis

```{r multivariate}
# PCA
X <- df[numerical_cols]
X_scaled <- scale(X)
pca_result <- prcomp(X_scaled)

# Scree plot
plot(pca_result$sdev^2 / sum(pca_result$sdev^2), 
    type = "o", main = "Scree Plot",
    xlab = "Principal Component", ylab = "Explained Variance")
```

## Summary

This analysis provides comprehensive univariate, bivariate, and multivariate insights.
